message:
Any suggestion about easy to use and user intuitive UI controls for asp.net MVC projects ?
And if any open source projects used these ui controls?

data.message:
If you are happy to pay, Kendo UI.
Otherwise maybe jQuery UI yeah. There are some HTML helper wrappers for it, but I suggest you use the JS stuff directly. We're using it in a very large banking project that has been going for over 2 years now.

But I've a lot of problems when merging Jquery UI controls into my MVC project and i think it's about JS files conflict and i spend a lot of time try to solve why the control doesn't appear or work correctly,
Any suggestions about linking JS files (Jquery , Jquery UI , other JS libs) without conflicts ?
Thank's A lot for your collaboration :)
Nothing special, just load jQuery first, then jQuery UI, then your custom scripts. Don't override global objects unless you know what you are doing.

I remember once I had a problem with jQuery UI not loading, turned out the original template added another jQuery reference in another place in the document after my jQuery and jQuery UI references, causing jQuery to be loaded twice and the 2nd one after jQuery UI.

yeah this actually happened to me also :( , but i'm wondering now when trying to merge some open source controls within the page which has Jquery already linked and the controls don't appear or work correctly???
Your browser concolse is the first place to check in this case. And also all sanity checks like reviewing generated HTML for anything weird like the problem I mentioned above.
it made me very angry actually, and feel like i'm a scriptkiddy

This is not jQuery UI specific, I lead the UI team in a very large project as I told you, and we developed tens of custom widgets on top of jQuery UI actually, even our application JS code is built using jQuery UI Widget factory. I'm also talking about 30-70 developers in Australia, US and India. It WORKS :)
yeah i'm every time go through this process of debugging, but as you know when it debugging goes to JQuery.js (and other long files) you don't figure it out (the proplem)
Usually you get the stack trace, track it to the last sight in your custom files.
ok i'll try it again, and wish me luck :)
Don't worry. Debugging JS is possible. I have been doing it more than anything else (well, except writing emails maybe) in the last year or so :D
